newsitem.title: LEBANON: Beirut t-bill issue raises 426 bln pounds.
newsitem.headline: Beirut t-bill issue raises 426 bln pounds.

text.p: Lebanon's weekly treasury bill issue of March 27 raised 426 billion Lebanese pounds after the Bank of Lebanon restricted sales of most bills.
The previous issue raised 366 billion pounds.
The issue posted a nominal surplus of subscription against maturity of 138 billion pounds. It raised the following amounts (in billion of pounds, previous week in brackets):

The central bank said only 13 percent of all competitive bids -- those made by Lebanese institutions -- were accepted up to the discount rate and yield for three-month bills and 14 percent for six-month bills. It was three percent for 12-month and 10 percent for two-year bills.

The Bank also restricted the acceptance of non-competitive bids -- those made by private individuals and foreign investors -- for three- and six-month bills. It approved only 13 percent up to the discount rate and yield for three-month bills and 14 percent for six-month bills.
However, all non-competitive bids for 12-month and 24-month bills were accepted, the Bank said.
The Lebanese pound closed at 1,545.5 to the U.S. dollar on Monday from 1,546.25 a week earlier and 1,583 a year ago.
